ygData.subject: Re: Placement of conceptually different inputs in HyperNEAT?

Peter,

Given an arbitrary point "P" in design space, comprised of the 
fol=
lowing:
(a) problem specific inputs (PSIs);
(b) auxiliary additional parame=
ters associated w/ PSIs;
(c) problem specific outputs (PSOs);
(d) auxiliary=
 additional parameters associated w/ PSOs;

Substrate Inputs: comprised of =
PSIs, "a" above;
Substrate Outputs: comprised of PSOs, "c" above;

Hypercub=
e Inputs: comprised of auxiliary additional parameters 
associated w/ PSIs =
& PSOs, "b" & "d" above;
Hypercube Output: weight between current pair of s=
ubstrate nodes

If:
(1) the dimensionality of the hypercube input "from" no=
de is 
different in number and/or nature as the links in the substrate 
net=
work are looped over, or
(2)  the dimensionality of the hypercube input "to=
" node is different 
in number and/or nature as the links in the substrate =
network are 
looped over,

...then the topology of the hypercube inputs are=
 different/change as 
you loop over the substrate links, while computing th=
e current link 
weight with the hypercube network.

   The examples and exp=
lanations provided to date do not address this 
more general condition.

  =
 Does this explain the issue in question better?

Thanks,
   Andy Carl


--=
- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" 
<petar_chervenski@...> wrote=
:
>
> Hi Andy, 
> 
> I am sorry, but I didn't understand what you mean by "=
hypercube 
input 
> topology"? 
> As far as I know, this is simply a CPPN t=
aking 2 points from the 
> substrate space (connective CPPN) instead of onl=
y one (spatial 
CPPN). 
> The coordinates of this points in the substrate s=
pace are the 
inputs 
> to this CPPN and the output is the weight/point int=
ensity. 
> The topology between these inputs and the output node is evolved=
 
with 
> the regular NEAT method. The evolved topology and the weights are=
 
the 
> most important thing to consider. 
> I guess this topology can cha=
nge? Maybe in time (leaky neurons) or 
> with recurrent connections?
> The =
idea of changing input topology for the CPPN is like 
> HyperHyperNEAT :) C=
PPNs that further create CPPNs..
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@...=
m, "afcarl2" <a.carl@> wrote:
> >
> > Ken,
> > 
> >    It appears that you =
keep attempting to recast the substrate 
> inputs 
> > and outputs such tha=
t the hypercube input topology remains 
> constant. 
> > Not taking anythin=
g away from HyperNEAT's ability to exploit 
> 1d/2d/3d 
> > geometry in whi=
ch the hypercube input topology remains constant, 
> the 
> > more general =
question of when the hypercube input topology is not 
> > constant, what do=
 you do? Please address this specific issue. The 
> > answer to this questi=
on will help to identify the 
> > applicability/limitations of HyperNEAT.
>=

> > Thanks,
> >    Andy Carl

uestion that highlights an important 
> area 
> > for

ch.  We can speculate on the right approach in 
this 
> > case 
> > > (and =
I have my hunches) but we won't know until we do some 
> > experiments 
> >=
 > and try ideas out.
> > > 
> > > To give some of my thoughts, perhaps the=
 most obvious thing is 
> > similar 
> > > to what you suggest:  Have two s=
eparate input sets, one for 
> > the "type A 
> > > info" and one for "type=
 B info."  
> > > 
> > > The way this would look is e.g. if A was 2D and B =
was 2D then 
the 
> > CPPN 
> > > would have 4 inputs, 2 represent A source=
 nodes and 2 
> representing 
> > B 
> > > soource nodes.
> > > 
> > > Then=
, I would still have only one set of outputs.  I am still a 
> > little 
> =
> > unclear on why you say the outputs are from the second 
> substrate?  
=
> > In 
> > > my understanding, this is still all one substrate, it's just =

that 
> > it 
> > > collects inputs from two different sources.  But it ca=
n still 
> exist 
> > > with only one set of outputs.  So if the outputs ar=
e 2D, the 
CPPN 
> > would 
> > > have 2 more inputs representing the outpu=
t area for a total of 
6 
> > inputs 
> > > (and one output representing th=
e weight of a connection in the 
> > > substrate).
> > > 
> > > If there wa=
s a hidden layer you could have it exist in either 
the 
> > same 
> > > ge=
ometry as A, the same geometry as B, or the same geometry as 
> the 
> > > =
outputs.  (For example by introducing a z dimension to any of 
> > these)  =

> > > Or you could have each kind of hidden layer all at once.
> > > 
> > =
> Of course, as you note, there are a lot of ways to do something 
> > like=
 
> > > this.  I think it will be a great issue to explore, but it may 
> >=
 require 
> > > starting with a very simple domain that isolates the issue =

(i.e. 
> > > orthogonal input types) so we can concentrate on that rather =

than 
> > on a 
> > > specific domain with its own complications.
> > > 
>=
 > > One other issue to note is that even if two sets of inputs are 
in 
> =
> > effect unrelated, it may not necessarily hurt antyhing to put 
> them 
=
> > in 
> > > the same geometry.  For example, they could be two separate 
=
> planes 
> > in 
> > > the same cube.  On the face of it, it seems like th=
at could 
cause 
> > > problems, but we don't yet know whether the situatio=
n is that 
> > difficult 
> > > to deal with in practice.  There could also=
 be hidden 
> relationships 
> > > that are not obvious but still exploitab=
le in a surprising way.
